1. Basic Types

libmygis provides two basic types which are used by GEOMETRY internally.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

1.1 POINT

The POINT type has two fields of type double: x and y. These are most commonly used to represent longitude and latitude, respectively.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

1.2 LINEARRING

The LINEARRING type has four fields: items, points, type, and area.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2. Geometries

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.1 Single Geometry Subtypes

A single geometry subtype is a type that contains only a single geometry; that is, a single point, linestring, or polygon. These are containers for the underlying basic types POINT and LINEARRING provided by mygis.h.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.1.1 GEOMETRY_POINT

The GEOMETRY_POINT type contains a single POINT as a pointer named point.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.1.2 GEOMETRY_LINESTRING

The GEOMETRY_LINESTRING type contains an array of POINT as a pointer named points, and a count of the items allocated at points in items.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.1.3 GEOMETRY_POLYGON

The GEOMETRY_POLYGON type contains an array of LINEARRING as a pointer named linearrings, and a count of the items allocated at linearrings in items. Although this type is considered a single polygon, it actually contains multiple polygons. The first polygon in linearrings contains the exterior rings (that is, the outer polygon). The following polygons in linearrings are any interior rings (that is, holes in the outer polygon). All interior rings must be within the boundaries of the exterior ring.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.2 Multiple Geometry Subtypes

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.2.1 GEOMETRY_MULTIPOINT

The GEOMETRY_MULTIPOINT type contains an array of GEOMETRY_POINT as a pointer named points, and a count of the items allocated at points in items.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.2.2 GEOMETRY_MULTILINESTRING

The GEOMETRY_MULTILINESTRING type contains an array of GEOMETRY_LINESTRING as a pointer named linestrings, and a count of the items allocated at linestrings in items.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.2.3 GEOMETRY_MULTIPOLYGON

The GEOMETRY_MULTIPOLYGON type contains an array of GEOMETRY_POLYGON as a pointer named polygons, and a count of the items allocated at polygons in items.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.3 Geometry Collections

The GEOMETRYCOLLECTION type is represented in the code but is not currently supported.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.4 The GEOMETRY container

The GEOMETRY type is normally used by any function that needs to return an arbitrary geometry. The type field determines its type, and the value field contains the actual geometry. The mbr field contains the minimum bounding rectangle for the geometry. The info field contains any number of key/value pairs.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.4.1 GEOMETRY_TYPE

The GEOMETRY_TYPE type is an enumeration of the possible geometry types which could be stored in a GEOMETRY_ANY. Its possible values are: T_NULL, T_POINT, T_LINESTRING, T_POLYGON, T_MULTIPOINT, T_MULTILINESTRING, T_MULTIPOLYGON, and T_GEOMETRYCOLLECTION.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.4.2 GEOMETRY_ANY

The GEOMETRY_ANY type is a union of all possible geometry types, which can be used combined with a GEOMETRY_TYPE field which stores the actual type stored in the GEOMETRY_ANY. The union presents the following pointer fields with their appropriate types: point, linestring, polygon, multipoint, multilinestring, multipolygon.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.4.3 GEOMETRY_MBR

The GEOMETRY_MBR type is used to store minimum bounding rectangles for geometries. It contains two POINT fields, min and max.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.4.4 GEOMETRY_INFO

This is currently unused?

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5 The geometry.h API

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5.1 geometry_init

GEOMETRY *geometry_init(GEOMETRY_TYPE type)

Initialize a GEOMETRY object of type type and return it.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5.2 geometry_set_projection

void geometry_set_projection(GEOMETRY *geometry, PROJECTION *projection)

Set the projection field in the GEOMETRY structure, which is currently only used within the geometry code by geometry_dump to re-project the contents of the geometry for display. geometry_set_projection should be called after initializing geometries with geometry_init by any code which is creating geometries.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5.3 geometry_dump

void geometry_dump(GEOMETRY *geometry)

Dump the contents of geometry to stdout in a pretty-printed form for debugging and test purposes. Optionally re-project any POINT that is dumped from the geometry by calling geometry_point_reproject if the user as set the projection with geometry_set_projection.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5.4 geometry_free

void geometry_free(GEOMETRY *geometry)

Free all memory associated with geometry.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5.5 Miscellaneous Functions

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5.5.1 geometry_point_reproject

POINT geometry_point_reproject(POINT *point, PROJECTION *projection)

Re-project point using projection and return a new POINT with the new projection.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

2.5.5.2 geometry_linearring_area

double geometry_linearring_area(LINEARRING *linearring)

Calculate the area represented by the linearring and return it as a double. This will return a number which may be positive or negative. The absolute value represents the area of the linear ring. If the value is positive, the ring is composed of clockwise points, while if it is negative, the ring is composed of counter-clockwise points. This can be used to determine if this is an interior or exterior ring in many GIS formats, such as WKB, where the exterior ring is represented by counter-clockwise points and the interior rings are represented by clockwise points.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

5. Shapefiles

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

5.3 The SHAPEFILE_SCAN container

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

5.4 The shapefile.h API

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

5.4.1 shapefile_init

SHAPEFILE *shapefile_init(int flags)

Initialize a SHAPEFILE and return it. The flags argument should be a bitwise-or of zero or more of the following values:

  • SHAPEFILE_NO_SHP Don't attempt to open an .shp (shape) file; no GEOMETRY will be available for each SHAPEFILE_RECORD. Implies SHAPEFILE_NO_SHX.

  • SHAPEFILE_NO_SHX Don't attempt to open a .shx (shape index) file; seeking within the shapefile using shapefile_seek_record will be much slower.

  • SHAPEFILE_NO_DBF Don't attempt to open a .dbf (database) file; no additional field information will be available for each SHAPEFILE_RECORD.

  • SHAPEFILE_NO_PRJ Don't attempt to open a .prj (projection) file; no automatic re-projection of geometries will be possible.

[ < ] [ > ]   [ << ] [ Up ] [ >> ]         [Top] [Contents] [Index] [ ? ]

int shapefile_open(SHAPEFILE *shapefile, char *basename, char mode)
